noun.description: The thick white or pale yellow fatty liquid which rises to the top when milk is left to stand and which can be eaten as an accompaniment to desserts or used as a cooking ingredient.
A thick liquid or semisolid cosmetic or medical preparation applied to the skin.
The very best of a group of people or things.
examples: the paper's readership is the cream of American society

noun.description: A very pale yellow or off-white color.
examples: the dress is available in white or cream

verb.description: Work (butter, typically with sugar) to form a smooth soft paste.
Rub a cosmetic cream into (the skin)
examples: Madge was creaming her face in front of the mirror

verb.description: Defeat (someone) heavily, especially in a sports contest.
(of a person) be sexually aroused to the point of producing sexual secretions.

phrases: the researchers and institutions in this network are the cream of the crop
The cast may not be the cream of the crop.
In sports, the cream of the crop is skimmed at each level.
He seemed the cream of the crop, loads of experience!
The cream of the crop was selected to play for the national team.
the schools cream off some of the better students
His argument is that grammar schools depress standards by creaming off the most able pupils.
Who historically has skimmed the cream off the top?
Of course, the small integrated schools will cream off a lot of the glory because of their name and ethos.
The result has been destructive with top schools creaming off the best talent.
origin: Middle English: from Old French cresme, from a blend of late Latin cramum (probably of Gaulish origin) and ecclesiastical Latin chrisma (see chrism).
